transformed_texts:
I reckon the Catholic Church needs to update its thinking in a few ways. 

Folks are saying the Church is losing followers, and I think it's partly because they aren't very accepting of things like gay marriage, abortion, and birth control. See, the Church has strong opinions on these matters, which is fine, but some of those views feel a bit outdated. 

I think if they were a bit more open-minded, they wouldn't have to worry about people leaving. 

I've heard that some folks are turning away from the Church because they disagree with their stance on these issues. They feel the Church has the wrong perspective. 

Take abortion, for example. If you believe in a woman's right to choose, you might not feel comfortable in a place that condemns it. It's the same with gay marriage. If you support it, you might not want to belong to a group that doesn't.

Personally, I don't see why they can't have female priests or allow priests to marry.  But I'm not sure if that would have stopped recent scandals. 

It's tough to say if being married or having women priests would have changed things. It's just hard to know.

I mean, the Church says priests are "married to God," but everyone else has a job and a family life. Why can't priests have both?

Hmm...this whole gay marriage thing, you know? I'm not against it at all.  I just don't think it's a choice people make, like deciding to be this way or that.  It's just how they are, right?  So why should we judge them for it?  It seems unfair to say a man and a woman can marry, but two people of the same sex can't.

To be honest, I haven't really thought about it too much. But it just feels wrong to me, like saying someone's love is less valid because of who they love.

Honestly, I don't think the government should be involved. It's not like a legal issue or a moral one, at least not in my opinion. It's just about people loving each other.  Why should we put them on display like they did something wrong?  We shouldn't be punishing people for who they are.

It just seems like the government has no business interfering in people's lives like this. It's about love, and love shouldn't be controlled.

Okay, so like, I think gay marriage should totally be legal. Why not, right?  Some folks think gay couples are bad news for straight families, but that's just not true. They're different, you know? Like, two sides of the same coin - same thing, different flips.  It's all about rights, too.  Stuff like taxes and health care. Like, if you're sick, your partner can't be there for you if you're not officially family.  Isn't that crazy? If you're gonna spend your life with someone, shouldn't they be there for you?  And studies show that gay couples are just as happy as straight couples.  It's the same deal! The thing is, people get hung up on this idea that gay marriage is about churches, but it's really just about a legal document.  Like, why can't the government recognize their relationship? It's like separate but unequal - it doesn't make sense.  

People worry about adoption and stuff, but honestly, gay parents are just like straight parents. They love their kids, they care for them.  It's about the individuals, not their sexual orientation.  I've heard stories about kids of gay parents getting bullied, which is awful.  But that's society's problem, not the parents.

The government should totally get involved and make gay marriage legal everywhere. It's about basic rights and equality.  It's frustrating that some people base their opinions on religion and morality, but everyone's beliefs are different.  It's not fair to impose one group's views on everyone else. And honestly, some people think gay people are broken or damaged, which is just wrong. Science has proven that's not true.

Okay, so like, I work at a hospital pharmacy during the summer. And you know, just because something's illegal doesn't mean it can't be good for you, right?  I mean, I don't think it should be legal for everyone to just buy it, no way. But for medicine, I think it should be okay.  It's not like just because it's illegal, it's automatically bad.  There are lots of drugs pharmacies use that are illegal, like oxycodone, Vicodin, Percocet – those are all controlled, but we use them all the time because they help people.  It's kinda messed up to say it's not okay just because people have a bad image of marijuana.  We gotta look at the good stuff it can do.


It's not like alcohol, though, because you can really get addicted to it if you're not careful. But you can with alcohol too, so it's tricky.  Maybe we should make it legal gradually, not all at once, you know?  That way people can get used to it and learn to use it responsibly.  

People think marijuana is so bad just because it's illegal. But it's not as bad as heroin or cocaine, for sure. If we change how people think about it, maybe they'll use it responsibly, especially for medicine.

Hmm... you know, I think churches have changed a lot since, like, the early 2000s. They're not as strict as they used to be. When I was little, I went to church every Sunday. I always wore these cute dresses and matching shoes and purses, you know, the whole nine yards. I went to a private school, and all my friends were there on the weekends. We'd just hang out. But now, they have this thing called Teen Mass – it's only thirty minutes long! And people dress so casually, especially in the summer. They come straight from the beach, in their swimsuits! Even at the morning masses, where I used to dress up fancy, now people wear jeans and khakis. It's a lot more relaxed.  That's the biggest change I've noticed.  

Oh, and I don't really know about all the church politics, but yeah, that's basically it. 

As for those accusations against priests, I don't think letting women be priests or letting priests get married would have stopped that.  Some married men become pedophiles too, right? It's not about whether they're married or not. It's about the person.

I mean, there are religions where priests can get married, like in that show "Seventh Heaven."  They have ministers who are married.  If someone really wants to practice their faith and be married, they could look into a different religion.

I think it's mostly genetic, you know? People are born that way. Maybe their upbringing plays a little part, but I think it's mostly in their genes. You can't really change that even with marriage.

Ugh,  you know, I was okay with the idea at first, but everyone was still super shaken up from 9/11.  I think we went into Iraq under false pretenses.  The Bush administration kept saying Saddam Hussein was involved with Osama Bin Laden and had weapons of mass destruction, but it turned out to be a big lie. It really makes me mad! 

I just think the Bush administration straight-up lied to the American people and still hasn't admitted it. Even Colin Powell, who gave that big speech at the UN about it, now says he wasn't really convinced by the evidence back then! That's just wrong, you know? It feels like they don't even care about the Constitution anymore. 

I think they went into office wanting to go to war.  There was even this guy, the Treasury Secretary, who wrote a book after he got kicked out of office, saying basically that. It seems like George W. Bush had a personal vendetta against Saddam Hussein because of what happened to his dad. Plus, I think he also wanted to control Iraq's oil. 

This whole thing has gone on for way too long. Pulling out right now could cause chaos and more people getting hurt. It seems they're trying to get other countries like Syria and Saudi Arabia to help stabilize things, but I don't know if that's a good idea either. It could mess up Iraq's sovereignty even more.

The government there is falling apart. The Prime Minister doesn't really have any power, and even that guy we were fighting, al-Sadr, his party now has a lot of seats in Parliament. It's all so complicated and messy.

So, like, I'm not really sure what to say about the war in Iraq. It feels pointless, you know? It wasn't even a real war, like, they never officially declared it. It just feels like we went in there to get back at them for 9/11, like we were just punishing them. 

I don't follow the war too closely, so I don't know all the details. But it seems like we're just staying there to try and build democracy, which is a good thing, I guess, but it's taking forever. And then there's the oil, which is like, a major factor. 

But honestly, it's just making everyone unhappy. If we stay, we're stuck trying to force democracy on them, which isn't going to happen overnight. And if we leave, they'll be mad because we messed everything up and left them to deal with it on their own. It's a total mess.

This is a tough one, because I don't really know what to think. I feel bad for the soldiers and their families, and I want them to be safe. But I also worry about how this is making everyone feel. It's like we're creating more problems than we're solving.

I think it's important to help, but it feels like we're just prolonging the conflict. And honestly, it's making Bush look bad. This could end up being another Vietnam, where we're seen as the bad guys.

Okay, so I just don't think it's right for the government to make this legal or illegal.  I mean, our constitution clearly states separation of church and state, right? To try and make laws about this would be going against what's already written.  

It seems to me like people pushing to make it illegal are just picking one church's beliefs over others. Like, most Catholics and Christians are against it, except for maybe in some spots like Boston.  But it shouldn't be up to the government to decide what churches can and can't do.  

Separation of church and state is super important for religious freedom in the US.  Even trying to make an amendment about this would be wrong, because it would go against the constitution and it would be one of the few amendments that restricts people instead of the government.

I don't think any government should be involved in this.  The guy pushing for this amendment is just trying to force his own Catholic beliefs on everyone else.  It's up to the churches to decide, not the president or any politician. There's no good reason to ban it, it won't help the economy or anything, and it might even be good for society.

Ok, so about the war in Iraq... I don't think our government was totally straight with the people about why we went in.  Before the invasion, they tried to connect it to the 9/11 attacks, even though they weren't really related.  They really played on people's emotions about 9/11 to get support for the war, which started in 2003.

Personally, I'm against war, especially when we attack first. I think this war is like a repeat of Vietnam, and we should have learned from those mistakes.  So many American soldiers have died, and it's heartbreaking.

They went in and took out the Iraqi government, but they weren't ready for what came next – the chaos and power vacuum.  They tried to put in a democracy, like they did in Vietnam, pushing out communism and trying to make democracy work.  

But they should have known it would be a long, hard fight. It's not like Vietnam was a clear victory, either. Even with support from some Iraqis, there were so many insurgents. It's hard to fight a war against your own people. 

Basically, I think we shouldn't have gone to war in the first place. But if we were going to do it, we should have planned better. They weren't ready for what happened after they removed the Iraqi government. We're still there, almost at the end of 2006, and American troops are still dying. They're trying to train Iraqi troops and police, but it's a slow process.  

I think the government tried to make it seem like it would be a quick, easy win, but it's not.  Building a new government takes time and struggle – just look at our own history. It wasn't easy to get to the government we have today.  

So, what now? It's tough because we've been there so long. How can we just leave them after we took their government and way of life?  But how many more American lives are we willing to risk for a free Iraq?

If we're going to make countries democratic, why just Iraq? Why not others? I think it's partly about oil – that's where we get it from.  

We thought Iraq had weapons of mass destruction, but they weren't there.  Meanwhile, we know North Korea has them, but we're not attacking them.  I don't think the government is being honest enough about its reasons.  

I just hope it ends soon and there's peace there. But I'm not sure if that will happen.

Um, let me tell you, I'm all for gay marriage, always have been. I truly believe it's a personal choice, something that science is showing more and more is likely biological, not a matter of choice.  It just feels wrong to take away someone's rights based on something they can't control. It's just not fair.  

I've always been a supporter of gay marriage.  I don't think politics or the government should have any say in this. It's a personal matter, something that happens between two people, within their homes and families.

You know, back home, there are a couple of openly gay couples in my neighborhood. They aren't married because they aren't allowed to, but they live their lives just like any other family. They walk their dogs, they go about their day, just like everyone else. 

It just seems ridiculous to me that someone like Bush wants to decide what marriage means and how it should be defined. It's their personal lives, not his to control.

I've read and heard a lot about how being gay might be something that's actually in your genes, a chemical thing in your brain. It could be something you're born with, not something you choose.  It's different from growing up in a certain environment or with certain influences. That's the biological side of it versus the sociological side.

The biggest thing that bothers me is the double standard.  If a guy and a girl want to get married, they can just elope to Vegas, no big deal. But if two gay people want to do the same thing, it becomes a huge public spectacle. It feels like it should be a private matter, something that doesn't need to be in the news or debated by politicians. It's not the government's business.

Ooooh, man, posting things online? That's a tricky one.  It's like, totally public, you know? Once something's out there, it's out there for everyone to see. As a Resident Advisor, I've had to deal with this stuff before. If you put something out there, it can totally change how people see you.  Like, if you're talking about blowing things up or, yikes, shootings, people are gonna freak out. You just can't put that kind of stuff out there. The internet is like, everywhere, man.

Think about it, if you're friends with someone on Myspace, you get their bulletins. It's not like the school got a special message, someone went to the school and told them. They have to do something, right? What if something actually happened? They'd feel awful if they didn't act on it.  

But then again, it's hard to know what's serious and what's not.  Sometimes people are just messing around, you know? Like maybe the situation at school was just a big misunderstanding - maybe it was a project gone wrong for a sociology class or something. Or maybe it was something really serious.

What happened was, someone heard someone else talking about something at school and told the authorities.  Then, they found out who it was, and they looked through their Facebook. There were some things on there that were kinda dark, and even though the person might have meant them as a joke, in the situation it sounded really serious.

The thing is, when you put stuff online, there's no privacy.  If you don't want people to see it, don't put it online! You can't control what people think or how they take things. I don't think school officials should be friending their students on Myspace and Facebook and snooping through their stuff, but if someone brings something to their attention, they have to take it seriously.

I mean, they shouldn't be listening to their students' phone calls or messages, but if someone tells them something, they have to do something about it. It's not cool for teachers to make fake profiles and friend their students, either - that's just wrong. I wouldn't want my residents to be able to see my life on Facebook, you know? It's just not my place to share that kind of stuff.

This war has just dragged on for far too long.  I remember when we first started, the goal was good – to help bring democracy to a country that needed it. But somewhere along the way, I think we lost sight of that. Now it feels like we're just fighting for the sake of fighting, trying to show everyone how powerful we are.

Honestly, I even wonder about the reasons we started this in the first place.  There were those old issues between George Bush's father and Saddam Hussein, weren't there?  If we truly wanted to bring democracy to a country without a fair system, that would be a good reason to fight. But if it was about personal grudges, that wouldn't be right.

I think we made our point those first few months, when we began the war. That was a powerful statement in itself. But it's been years now, and it just seems to be going on and on.

I think if our goal was to help a country ruled by a tyrant, that was a noble reason to start. But over time, I feel like our reasons have become blurred and confused. It feels like we're fighting for the sake of fighting, needing to win and declare victory.

This war has gone on long enough. It's time to stop.  Eventually, their government and people will have to figure things out on their own. We've already drained our own economy, spending billions of dollars on this war when we have so many problems right here at home – poverty, healthcare, education... These are things we should be using that money for.

Billions and billions are being spent on a war that no longer has a clear purpose. We have our own problems that need attention, like fixing roads, improving schools, and taking care of our citizens.  It's heartbreaking to see our money being spent to kill our own people in a foreign country for a cause that has been lost.

Okay, so basically, someone found out about something on Myspace that could have been really bad, and they stopped it from happening. Is it wrong to look at other people's Myspace profiles?  

I don't think it's an invasion of privacy. If you put stuff on Myspace, it's kind of public.  I mean, yeah, you need to be friends with someone to see their profile, but you're choosing to be their friend, so you're giving them permission to see it.

When you post things online, you have to understand that lots of people might see them. So, I think it was actually good that someone saw that and stopped something bad from happening.

But, it's tough because you can't have someone watching everyone's Myspace all day. It wouldn't be fair to single out certain students and check their profiles just because they might be up to something.

Maybe it depends on the situation. If someone was looking for something specific, like evidence of a student planning something dangerous, then maybe it's different. But if someone was just randomly looking through profiles, that wouldn't be right.

I don't have Myspace, but I have Facebook, and it worries me that there are people out there who can see all this information about me. I saw a story on TV about a guy who could easily find someone's personal information online and even get them to meet up with him in just a few minutes.

I definitely wouldn't do that! I've had people in my classes message me on Facebook even though I don't recognize their names. It's creepy because they seem to know so much about me - my interests, what I look like, my class schedule, even my friends.

I try to be careful about what I post, but it's hard. I use Facebook to connect with friends, so I don't want to limit it too much.

I only accept friend requests from people I know, but you never really know who can see what. It's a tricky issue. 

I heard that some high schools banned Myspace, which seems strange to me. How can the school tell students they can't have a Myspace? I'm not sure if it's a privacy issue, but I don't know if they have the right to do that.

Honestly, this whole Iraq War thing makes me feel kind of hypocritical. I mean, I hate to jump on the bandwagon and say I was against it from the start, but I was. It's just that now, it feels like everyone agrees it was a bad idea, except maybe those in power who don't want to admit they were wrong.  

Everywhere you look, the polls show it - Americans, Iraqis, people all over the world - about 75 to 80% think it was a mistake. Even a lot of the U.S. troops there think it was a bad call and we should get out. 

To me, it's been a disaster from the get-go.  Even before we got involved, it was a mess, and now leaving is going to be another disaster.  It's like quicksand.  

I think it's just a clash of cultures, you know?  The U.S. and the Middle East are so different. This administration, and even the ones before it, just don't understand. They think they can force democracy on a place where it doesn't fit.  

Sure, Saddam was a bad guy, but you have to weigh the pros and cons before invading a country.  It's just turned into a complete nightmare.

Frankly, I don't see any reason to stay. I'm sure the government has some hopeful ideas about staying, but I haven't heard a good one yet. If they want to pull out gradually, over a year or so, I wouldn't mind that.  But just leaving now seems like the best option. 

I read that 80% of Iraqis want us out within a year, and a quarter of them want us out now. They're the ones we're trying to help, and they're telling us to leave. Maybe they know best. 

If we ask them if we should leave and they say yes, at least we can't be blamed if things go bad. We could say, "Well, you guys made the decision."

At least then, if we decide to help out later, we'll be seen as the good guys.  Well, maybe not the *good* guys, but better than we are now.

Honestly, I think gender bias is still a real issue in the United States. It's not just about women, though. It often depends on the field you work in. 

I feel women face a tougher time because of the "glass ceiling." Even though equality is the goal, many struggle to find themselves leading a team with a woman at the top.  This is because of how society has always been, you know?  Women often have the skills and qualifications for a higher position, but the board might not choose them because historically, women haven't been in those high-powered roles.  

And it's similar for men, too. Think about fields like fashion or being a stay-at-home parent. 

It's uncommon to see a man at home taking care of the kids. People often criticize that choice because society expects men to be the breadwinners. 

It can be tough on men who want to stay home with their children, especially if their wives are the ones with the better job. It's working for their family, but society doesn't always understand. 

In fashion, some people might not take a straight male seriously if he's into it. Maybe it's because they think men who are into fashion have a different lifestyle. So, if a guy fits the stereotypical "masculine" mold and works in fashion, people might question his knowledge and expertise.

So, I believe there's definitely gender bias in the US, but it varies depending on the industry. 

Changing it is tough because society has deeply ingrained ideas. We've made progress, but it's slow. We're seeing more women in leadership roles and stay-at-home dads becoming more accepted.  Slowly, people are starting to understand.

To really shift things, we need to highlight the good qualities of those who are stereotyped. We can't be pushy, but we need to show that these individuals are valuable and deserving of respect. 

It's a delicate balance. Change takes time, and we're making progress, but we still have a long way to go.

So, they didn't actually make it legal, they just took it off the criminal list.  Now it's more like a ticket, you know, like parking. You get a citation, not hauled off to jail. I think, if you get caught now, it won't be as bad for your job or anything like that.  The big worries people have, especially the young ones, is what happens later, even after it's not a crime.  But, it costs a lot of money to arrest folks, take them to court, and deal with all that. It's a lot of money, money that could be used for schools or helping people.   Places that are struggling financially, they just don't want to part with that money, even if it means letting people go for smaller stuff. Some places are just against marijuana, no matter what.  But in places like Denver, where people are more open-minded, I think it makes sense. They probably have more money now to spend on good things.

I mean, you don't want marijuana everywhere, in every shop, like cigarettes. That would be a problem. But the money thing is important too. There are other reasons why it might not be good to be totally open about it, you know? Like, it's still not accepted in many places, and having it out in the open could feel weird.   

Um, you know what I mean? What was that? I can't hear you well.

I think alcohol is worse for your driving, but marijuana can mess with your whole life more. Both have bad effects, but people react differently. Some people can handle anything, and some can't. It's hard to say what's better or worse, because everyone is different.

Hmm, I'd say being Catholic has its pros and cons. On one hand, they have strong traditions and stick to them, which can be good for stability. But it's also important to be open to change, you know? Like, a lot of Catholics are super strict about going to church every week and following the rules. Sometimes it feels like they judge those who don't follow everything perfectly or even people from other religions.  Take my parents for example, my mom was Catholic and my dad was Episcopalian. They wouldn't let them marry in the Catholic Church because of my dad's faith. That doesn't seem very accepting to me, you know?  It's like they say to love everyone, but then they don't act like it. 

It's like the rules sometimes seem old-fashioned and don't match up with what they preach.  

Some people think letting priests marry would be a good thing, but I don't think it would stop bad things from happening.  I mean, people who hurt kids probably wouldn't stop just because they're married. It's a different kind of issue altogether.

Hmmm... this whole thing, it's really got me thinking. I'm still not sure what I think about it all.

It's tough to say who's right or wrong, y'know? But this issue, it's the trickiest one we're facing right now. It's a real tangle between keeping church and state separate and figuring out what marriage really means.

It's hard to define marriage without upsetting someone.

I dunno, maybe all civil unions should just be treated the same way.

Marriage, should the government even define it?

I mean, if you get baptized, they don't give you special tax breaks or anything, right?

So why should they care if you're married?

To me, it's just a civil union: two people who want to be together.

They shouldn't mix religion with government stuff.

Just look at it as two people coming together.

And, you know, with gay marriage...

It's just two people wanting to be together.

Should they care what kind of marriage it is?

If all the states can agree on something sensible, they should make it a federal law.

But trying to ban gay marriage with a constitutional amendment? That's just silly.

The constitution shouldn't be changed for something like this.

It's important to people, sure, but not important enough for a major change like that.

It just doesn't feel right to me.

Hmm...this whole thing about homosexuality is kinda confusing for me.  You see, I grew up in a Christian family, so it's a bit of a grey area.  I have lots of gay friends, so I don't dislike them or anything.  I just don't personally agree with their lifestyle.

But, I do think they should have the right to marry.  It shouldn't be a big national issue, you know?  I feel like each state should decide for themselves whether or not to allow gay marriage.  It's not fair for the president to make that decision for the whole country.

Think about it, some states are very liberal, and others are more conservative.  Liberal states are more likely to support gay marriage, and if you live in one of those states, you kinda have to accept their views, right?  

I believe everyone should have the same opportunities, whether they're gay or straight.  So, I think it should be up to each state to decide about gay marriage.

Honestly, I don't think it's right for the president to ban it nationwide.  Each state should be able to make its own choice.  He doesn't live in every state, so he shouldn't get to decide how they run things.

Plus, he's leaving office soon anyway.  If a new president comes in who supports gay marriage, they can just overturn the ban.  It's just going to be a constant back-and-forth.  It's better to let each state decide for themselves.  They're the ones who will have to live with the consequences of their decision.

Okay, so, think about it this way. Myspace is like a public bulletin board, right? Anything you put on there is for everyone to see, not just your friends.  So, if school officials can see it, even if they aren't using the school's name, it's not really a big deal. 

I mean, if they're checking Myspace to make sure students aren't doing anything dangerous, like drinking or smoking, that's different. It's like they're trying to catch kids doing something wrong, which is kind of wrong. But if they're trying to prevent something bad from happening, like a school shooting, then I think it's okay.  

It's all about keeping everyone safe, you know?  Schools have a responsibility to protect their students, and sometimes that means looking into things even if it feels a little bit like an invasion of privacy. 

Plus, think about it, if you post something on the internet, it's out there forever. Even if you delete it, someone could have already seen it.

Okay, so, about this war... at first, I was totally for it. Nine Eleven hit me hard, you know? I was ready to dish out some payback, same as they did here. But looking back, I think our emotions got the best of us. We jumped in without a real plan, kinda unprepared. And it backfired big time. 

Honestly, I'm against it now. I don't think it achieved anything.  Those people over there, they're too busy fighting each other to bother with us.  They can't even get along, so what difference does us being there make?

Nine Eleven changed things for me. I just don't care what happens to them anymore. It's like they're not even human, the way they fight each other. They can't solve their own problems.

We went in there blind, not knowing what we were facing. War for them is different than it is for us. They're savage. They're not trying to build anything, they just want us out.  And honestly, I think we should just leave.

I think we were just hyped up by the whole thing, not thinking straight about the consequences. We were fueled by revenge, and President Bush just went along with it because the people wanted it. 

I get why he declared war on Iraq. We couldn't just let them get away with it. But we should've had a better plan. We were disorganized and unclear about our goals. There was no unity. 

We were driven by anger and emotion, and that's what we created over there. Honestly, I don't think we're capable of changing them. They'll always be like that.

I've said enough. It's been dragging on for too long. We've made some progress, but not enough to justify staying.  They'll just fall apart again once we leave. We can't be there forever.

transformed_texts:
I reckon the Catholic Church needs to update its thinking in a few ways. 

Folks are saying the Church is losing followers, and I think it's partly because they aren't very accepting of things like gay marriage, abortion, and birth control. See, the Church has strong opinions on these matters, which is fine, but some of those views feel a bit outdated. 

I think if they were a bit more open-minded, they wouldn't have to worry about people leaving. 

I've heard that some folks are turning away from the Church because they disagree with their stance on these issues. They feel the Church has the wrong perspective. 

Take abortion, for example. If you believe in a woman's right to choose, you might not feel comfortable in a place that condemns it. It's the same with gay marriage. If you support it, you might not want to belong to a group that doesn't.

Personally, I don't see why they can't have female priests or allow priests to marry.  But I'm not sure if that would have stopped recent scandals. 

It's tough to say if being married or having women priests would have changed things. It's just hard to know.

I mean, the Church says priests are "married to God," but everyone else has a job and a family life. Why can't priests have both?

Hmm...this whole gay marriage thing, you know? I'm not against it at all.  I just don't think it's a choice people make, like deciding to be this way or that.  It's just how they are, right?  So why should we judge them for it?  It seems unfair to say a man and a woman can marry, but two people of the same sex can't.

To be honest, I haven't really thought about it too much. But it just feels wrong to me, like saying someone's love is less valid because of who they love.

Honestly, I don't think the government should be involved. It's not like a legal issue or a moral one, at least not in my opinion. It's just about people loving each other.  Why should we put them on display like they did something wrong?  We shouldn't be punishing people for who they are.

It just seems like the government has no business interfering in people's lives like this. It's about love, and love shouldn't be controlled.

Okay, so like, I think gay marriage should totally be legal. Why not, right?  Some folks think gay couples are bad news for straight families, but that's just not true. They're different, you know? Like, two sides of the same coin - same thing, different flips.  It's all about rights, too.  Stuff like taxes and health care. Like, if you're sick, your partner can't be there for you if you're not officially family.  Isn't that crazy? If you're gonna spend your life with someone, shouldn't they be there for you?  And studies show that gay couples are just as happy as straight couples.  It's the same deal! The thing is, people get hung up on this idea that gay marriage is about churches, but it's really just about a legal document.  Like, why can't the government recognize their relationship? It's like separate but unequal - it doesn't make sense.  

People worry about adoption and stuff, but honestly, gay parents are just like straight parents. They love their kids, they care for them.  It's about the individuals, not their sexual orientation.  I've heard stories about kids of gay parents getting bullied, which is awful.  But that's society's problem, not the parents.

The government should totally get involved and make gay marriage legal everywhere. It's about basic rights and equality.  It's frustrating that some people base their opinions on religion and morality, but everyone's beliefs are different.  It's not fair to impose one group's views on everyone else. And honestly, some people think gay people are broken or damaged, which is just wrong. Science has proven that's not true.

Okay, so like, I work at a hospital pharmacy during the summer. And you know, just because something's illegal doesn't mean it can't be good for you, right?  I mean, I don't think it should be legal for everyone to just buy it, no way. But for medicine, I think it should be okay.  It's not like just because it's illegal, it's automatically bad.  There are lots of drugs pharmacies use that are illegal, like oxycodone, Vicodin, Percocet – those are all controlled, but we use them all the time because they help people.  It's kinda messed up to say it's not okay just because people have a bad image of marijuana.  We gotta look at the good stuff it can do.


It's not like alcohol, though, because you can really get addicted to it if you're not careful. But you can with alcohol too, so it's tricky.  Maybe we should make it legal gradually, not all at once, you know?  That way people can get used to it and learn to use it responsibly.  

People think marijuana is so bad just because it's illegal. But it's not as bad as heroin or cocaine, for sure. If we change how people think about it, maybe they'll use it responsibly, especially for medicine.

Hmm... you know, I think churches have changed a lot since, like, the early 2000s. They're not as strict as they used to be. When I was little, I went to church every Sunday. I always wore these cute dresses and matching shoes and purses, you know, the whole nine yards. I went to a private school, and all my friends were there on the weekends. We'd just hang out. But now, they have this thing called Teen Mass – it's only thirty minutes long! And people dress so casually, especially in the summer. They come straight from the beach, in their swimsuits! Even at the morning masses, where I used to dress up fancy, now people wear jeans and khakis. It's a lot more relaxed.  That's the biggest change I've noticed.  

Oh, and I don't really know about all the church politics, but yeah, that's basically it. 

As for those accusations against priests, I don't think letting women be priests or letting priests get married would have stopped that.  Some married men become pedophiles too, right? It's not about whether they're married or not. It's about the person.

I mean, there are religions where priests can get married, like in that show "Seventh Heaven."  They have ministers who are married.  If someone really wants to practice their faith and be married, they could look into a different religion.

I think it's mostly genetic, you know? People are born that way. Maybe their upbringing plays a little part, but I think it's mostly in their genes. You can't really change that even with marriage.

Ugh,  you know, I was okay with the idea at first, but everyone was still super shaken up from 9/11.  I think we went into Iraq under false pretenses.  The Bush administration kept saying Saddam Hussein was involved with Osama Bin Laden and had weapons of mass destruction, but it turned out to be a big lie. It really makes me mad! 

I just think the Bush administration straight-up lied to the American people and still hasn't admitted it. Even Colin Powell, who gave that big speech at the UN about it, now says he wasn't really convinced by the evidence back then! That's just wrong, you know? It feels like they don't even care about the Constitution anymore. 

I think they went into office wanting to go to war.  There was even this guy, the Treasury Secretary, who wrote a book after he got kicked out of office, saying basically that. It seems like George W. Bush had a personal vendetta against Saddam Hussein because of what happened to his dad. Plus, I think he also wanted to control Iraq's oil. 

This whole thing has gone on for way too long. Pulling out right now could cause chaos and more people getting hurt. It seems they're trying to get other countries like Syria and Saudi Arabia to help stabilize things, but I don't know if that's a good idea either. It could mess up Iraq's sovereignty even more.

The government there is falling apart. The Prime Minister doesn't really have any power, and even that guy we were fighting, al-Sadr, his party now has a lot of seats in Parliament. It's all so complicated and messy.

So, like, I'm not really sure what to say about the war in Iraq. It feels pointless, you know? It wasn't even a real war, like, they never officially declared it. It just feels like we went in there to get back at them for 9/11, like we were just punishing them. 

I don't follow the war too closely, so I don't know all the details. But it seems like we're just staying there to try and build democracy, which is a good thing, I guess, but it's taking forever. And then there's the oil, which is like, a major factor. 

But honestly, it's just making everyone unhappy. If we stay, we're stuck trying to force democracy on them, which isn't going to happen overnight. And if we leave, they'll be mad because we messed everything up and left them to deal with it on their own. It's a total mess.

This is a tough one, because I don't really know what to think. I feel bad for the soldiers and their families, and I want them to be safe. But I also worry about how this is making everyone feel. It's like we're creating more problems than we're solving.

I think it's important to help, but it feels like we're just prolonging the conflict. And honestly, it's making Bush look bad. This could end up being another Vietnam, where we're seen as the bad guys.

Okay, so I just don't think it's right for the government to make this legal or illegal.  I mean, our constitution clearly states separation of church and state, right? To try and make laws about this would be going against what's already written.  

It seems to me like people pushing to make it illegal are just picking one church's beliefs over others. Like, most Catholics and Christians are against it, except for maybe in some spots like Boston.  But it shouldn't be up to the government to decide what churches can and can't do.  

Separation of church and state is super important for religious freedom in the US.  Even trying to make an amendment about this would be wrong, because it would go against the constitution and it would be one of the few amendments that restricts people instead of the government.

I don't think any government should be involved in this.  The guy pushing for this amendment is just trying to force his own Catholic beliefs on everyone else.  It's up to the churches to decide, not the president or any politician. There's no good reason to ban it, it won't help the economy or anything, and it might even be good for society.

Ok, so about the war in Iraq... I don't think our government was totally straight with the people about why we went in.  Before the invasion, they tried to connect it to the 9/11 attacks, even though they weren't really related.  They really played on people's emotions about 9/11 to get support for the war, which started in 2003.

Personally, I'm against war, especially when we attack first. I think this war is like a repeat of Vietnam, and we should have learned from those mistakes.  So many American soldiers have died, and it's heartbreaking.

They went in and took out the Iraqi government, but they weren't ready for what came next – the chaos and power vacuum.  They tried to put in a democracy, like they did in Vietnam, pushing out communism and trying to make democracy work.  

But they should have known it would be a long, hard fight. It's not like Vietnam was a clear victory, either. Even with support from some Iraqis, there were so many insurgents. It's hard to fight a war against your own people. 

Basically, I think we shouldn't have gone to war in the first place. But if we were going to do it, we should have planned better. They weren't ready for what happened after they removed the Iraqi government. We're still there, almost at the end of 2006, and American troops are still dying. They're trying to train Iraqi troops and police, but it's a slow process.  

I think the government tried to make it seem like it would be a quick, easy win, but it's not.  Building a new government takes time and struggle – just look at our own history. It wasn't easy to get to the government we have today.  

So, what now? It's tough because we've been there so long. How can we just leave them after we took their government and way of life?  But how many more American lives are we willing to risk for a free Iraq?

If we're going to make countries democratic, why just Iraq? Why not others? I think it's partly about oil – that's where we get it from.  

We thought Iraq had weapons of mass destruction, but they weren't there.  Meanwhile, we know North Korea has them, but we're not attacking them.  I don't think the government is being honest enough about its reasons.  

I just hope it ends soon and there's peace there. But I'm not sure if that will happen.

Um, let me tell you, I'm all for gay marriage, always have been. I truly believe it's a personal choice, something that science is showing more and more is likely biological, not a matter of choice.  It just feels wrong to take away someone's rights based on something they can't control. It's just not fair.  

I've always been a supporter of gay marriage.  I don't think politics or the government should have any say in this. It's a personal matter, something that happens between two people, within their homes and families.

You know, back home, there are a couple of openly gay couples in my neighborhood. They aren't married because they aren't allowed to, but they live their lives just like any other family. They walk their dogs, they go about their day, just like everyone else. 

It just seems ridiculous to me that someone like Bush wants to decide what marriage means and how it should be defined. It's their personal lives, not his to control.

I've read and heard a lot about how being gay might be something that's actually in your genes, a chemical thing in your brain. It could be something you're born with, not something you choose.  It's different from growing up in a certain environment or with certain influences. That's the biological side of it versus the sociological side.

The biggest thing that bothers me is the double standard.  If a guy and a girl want to get married, they can just elope to Vegas, no big deal. But if two gay people want to do the same thing, it becomes a huge public spectacle. It feels like it should be a private matter, something that doesn't need to be in the news or debated by politicians. It's not the government's business.

Ooooh, man, posting things online? That's a tricky one.  It's like, totally public, you know? Once something's out there, it's out there for everyone to see. As a Resident Advisor, I've had to deal with this stuff before. If you put something out there, it can totally change how people see you.  Like, if you're talking about blowing things up or, yikes, shootings, people are gonna freak out. You just can't put that kind of stuff out there. The internet is like, everywhere, man.

Think about it, if you're friends with someone on Myspace, you get their bulletins. It's not like the school got a special message, someone went to the school and told them. They have to do something, right? What if something actually happened? They'd feel awful if they didn't act on it.  

But then again, it's hard to know what's serious and what's not.  Sometimes people are just messing around, you know? Like maybe the situation at school was just a big misunderstanding - maybe it was a project gone wrong for a sociology class or something. Or maybe it was something really serious.

What happened was, someone heard someone else talking about something at school and told the authorities.  Then, they found out who it was, and they looked through their Facebook. There were some things on there that were kinda dark, and even though the person might have meant them as a joke, in the situation it sounded really serious.

The thing is, when you put stuff online, there's no privacy.  If you don't want people to see it, don't put it online! You can't control what people think or how they take things. I don't think school officials should be friending their students on Myspace and Facebook and snooping through their stuff, but if someone brings something to their attention, they have to take it seriously.

I mean, they shouldn't be listening to their students' phone calls or messages, but if someone tells them something, they have to do something about it. It's not cool for teachers to make fake profiles and friend their students, either - that's just wrong. I wouldn't want my residents to be able to see my life on Facebook, you know? It's just not my place to share that kind of stuff.

This war has just dragged on for far too long.  I remember when we first started, the goal was good – to help bring democracy to a country that needed it. But somewhere along the way, I think we lost sight of that. Now it feels like we're just fighting for the sake of fighting, trying to show everyone how powerful we are.

Honestly, I even wonder about the reasons we started this in the first place.  There were those old issues between George Bush's father and Saddam Hussein, weren't there?  If we truly wanted to bring democracy to a country without a fair system, that would be a good reason to fight. But if it was about personal grudges, that wouldn't be right.

I think we made our point those first few months, when we began the war. That was a powerful statement in itself. But it's been years now, and it just seems to be going on and on.

I think if our goal was to help a country ruled by a tyrant, that was a noble reason to start. But over time, I feel like our reasons have become blurred and confused. It feels like we're fighting for the sake of fighting, needing to win and declare victory.

This war has gone on long enough. It's time to stop.  Eventually, their government and people will have to figure things out on their own. We've already drained our own economy, spending billions of dollars on this war when we have so many problems right here at home – poverty, healthcare, education... These are things we should be using that money for.

Billions and billions are being spent on a war that no longer has a clear purpose. We have our own problems that need attention, like fixing roads, improving schools, and taking care of our citizens.  It's heartbreaking to see our money being spent to kill our own people in a foreign country for a cause that has been lost.

Okay, so basically, someone found out about something on Myspace that could have been really bad, and they stopped it from happening. Is it wrong to look at other people's Myspace profiles?  

I don't think it's an invasion of privacy. If you put stuff on Myspace, it's kind of public.  I mean, yeah, you need to be friends with someone to see their profile, but you're choosing to be their friend, so you're giving them permission to see it.

When you post things online, you have to understand that lots of people might see them. So, I think it was actually good that someone saw that and stopped something bad from happening.

But, it's tough because you can't have someone watching everyone's Myspace all day. It wouldn't be fair to single out certain students and check their profiles just because they might be up to something.

Maybe it depends on the situation. If someone was looking for something specific, like evidence of a student planning something dangerous, then maybe it's different. But if someone was just randomly looking through profiles, that wouldn't be right.

I don't have Myspace, but I have Facebook, and it worries me that there are people out there who can see all this information about me. I saw a story on TV about a guy who could easily find someone's personal information online and even get them to meet up with him in just a few minutes.

I definitely wouldn't do that! I've had people in my classes message me on Facebook even though I don't recognize their names. It's creepy because they seem to know so much about me - my interests, what I look like, my class schedule, even my friends.

I try to be careful about what I post, but it's hard. I use Facebook to connect with friends, so I don't want to limit it too much.

I only accept friend requests from people I know, but you never really know who can see what. It's a tricky issue. 

I heard that some high schools banned Myspace, which seems strange to me. How can the school tell students they can't have a Myspace? I'm not sure if it's a privacy issue, but I don't know if they have the right to do that.

Honestly, this whole Iraq War thing makes me feel kind of hypocritical. I mean, I hate to jump on the bandwagon and say I was against it from the start, but I was. It's just that now, it feels like everyone agrees it was a bad idea, except maybe those in power who don't want to admit they were wrong.  

Everywhere you look, the polls show it - Americans, Iraqis, people all over the world - about 75 to 80% think it was a mistake. Even a lot of the U.S. troops there think it was a bad call and we should get out. 

To me, it's been a disaster from the get-go.  Even before we got involved, it was a mess, and now leaving is going to be another disaster.  It's like quicksand.  

I think it's just a clash of cultures, you know?  The U.S. and the Middle East are so different. This administration, and even the ones before it, just don't understand. They think they can force democracy on a place where it doesn't fit.  

Sure, Saddam was a bad guy, but you have to weigh the pros and cons before invading a country.  It's just turned into a complete nightmare.

Frankly, I don't see any reason to stay. I'm sure the government has some hopeful ideas about staying, but I haven't heard a good one yet. If they want to pull out gradually, over a year or so, I wouldn't mind that.  But just leaving now seems like the best option. 

I read that 80% of Iraqis want us out within a year, and a quarter of them want us out now. They're the ones we're trying to help, and they're telling us to leave. Maybe they know best. 

If we ask them if we should leave and they say yes, at least we can't be blamed if things go bad. We could say, "Well, you guys made the decision."

At least then, if we decide to help out later, we'll be seen as the good guys.  Well, maybe not the *good* guys, but better than we are now.

Honestly, I think gender bias is still a real issue in the United States. It's not just about women, though. It often depends on the field you work in. 

I feel women face a tougher time because of the "glass ceiling." Even though equality is the goal, many struggle to find themselves leading a team with a woman at the top.  This is because of how society has always been, you know?  Women often have the skills and qualifications for a higher position, but the board might not choose them because historically, women haven't been in those high-powered roles.  

And it's similar for men, too. Think about fields like fashion or being a stay-at-home parent. 

It's uncommon to see a man at home taking care of the kids. People often criticize that choice because society expects men to be the breadwinners. 

It can be tough on men who want to stay home with their children, especially if their wives are the ones with the better job. It's working for their family, but society doesn't always understand. 

In fashion, some people might not take a straight male seriously if he's into it. Maybe it's because they think men who are into fashion have a different lifestyle. So, if a guy fits the stereotypical "masculine" mold and works in fashion, people might question his knowledge and expertise.

So, I believe there's definitely gender bias in the US, but it varies depending on the industry. 

Changing it is tough because society has deeply ingrained ideas. We've made progress, but it's slow. We're seeing more women in leadership roles and stay-at-home dads becoming more accepted.  Slowly, people are starting to understand.

To really shift things, we need to highlight the good qualities of those who are stereotyped. We can't be pushy, but we need to show that these individuals are valuable and deserving of respect. 

It's a delicate balance. Change takes time, and we're making progress, but we still have a long way to go.

So, they didn't actually make it legal, they just took it off the criminal list.  Now it's more like a ticket, you know, like parking. You get a citation, not hauled off to jail. I think, if you get caught now, it won't be as bad for your job or anything like that.  The big worries people have, especially the young ones, is what happens later, even after it's not a crime.  But, it costs a lot of money to arrest folks, take them to court, and deal with all that. It's a lot of money, money that could be used for schools or helping people.   Places that are struggling financially, they just don't want to part with that money, even if it means letting people go for smaller stuff. Some places are just against marijuana, no matter what.  But in places like Denver, where people are more open-minded, I think it makes sense. They probably have more money now to spend on good things.

I mean, you don't want marijuana everywhere, in every shop, like cigarettes. That would be a problem. But the money thing is important too. There are other reasons why it might not be good to be totally open about it, you know? Like, it's still not accepted in many places, and having it out in the open could feel weird.   

Um, you know what I mean? What was that? I can't hear you well.

I think alcohol is worse for your driving, but marijuana can mess with your whole life more. Both have bad effects, but people react differently. Some people can handle anything, and some can't. It's hard to say what's better or worse, because everyone is different.

Hmm, I'd say being Catholic has its pros and cons. On one hand, they have strong traditions and stick to them, which can be good for stability. But it's also important to be open to change, you know? Like, a lot of Catholics are super strict about going to church every week and following the rules. Sometimes it feels like they judge those who don't follow everything perfectly or even people from other religions.  Take my parents for example, my mom was Catholic and my dad was Episcopalian. They wouldn't let them marry in the Catholic Church because of my dad's faith. That doesn't seem very accepting to me, you know?  It's like they say to love everyone, but then they don't act like it. 

It's like the rules sometimes seem old-fashioned and don't match up with what they preach.  

Some people think letting priests marry would be a good thing, but I don't think it would stop bad things from happening.  I mean, people who hurt kids probably wouldn't stop just because they're married. It's a different kind of issue altogether.

Hmmm... this whole thing, it's really got me thinking. I'm still not sure what I think about it all.

It's tough to say who's right or wrong, y'know? But this issue, it's the trickiest one we're facing right now. It's a real tangle between keeping church and state separate and figuring out what marriage really means.

It's hard to define marriage without upsetting someone.

I dunno, maybe all civil unions should just be treated the same way.

Marriage, should the government even define it?

I mean, if you get baptized, they don't give you special tax breaks or anything, right?

So why should they care if you're married?

To me, it's just a civil union: two people who want to be together.

They shouldn't mix religion with government stuff.

Just look at it as two people coming together.

And, you know, with gay marriage...

It's just two people wanting to be together.

Should they care what kind of marriage it is?

If all the states can agree on something sensible, they should make it a federal law.

But trying to ban gay marriage with a constitutional amendment? That's just silly.

The constitution shouldn't be changed for something like this.

It's important to people, sure, but not important enough for a major change like that.

It just doesn't feel right to me.

Hmm...this whole thing about homosexuality is kinda confusing for me.  You see, I grew up in a Christian family, so it's a bit of a grey area.  I have lots of gay friends, so I don't dislike them or anything.  I just don't personally agree with their lifestyle.

But, I do think they should have the right to marry.  It shouldn't be a big national issue, you know?  I feel like each state should decide for themselves whether or not to allow gay marriage.  It's not fair for the president to make that decision for the whole country.

Think about it, some states are very liberal, and others are more conservative.  Liberal states are more likely to support gay marriage, and if you live in one of those states, you kinda have to accept their views, right?  

I believe everyone should have the same opportunities, whether they're gay or straight.  So, I think it should be up to each state to decide about gay marriage.

Honestly, I don't think it's right for the president to ban it nationwide.  Each state should be able to make its own choice.  He doesn't live in every state, so he shouldn't get to decide how they run things.

Plus, he's leaving office soon anyway.  If a new president comes in who supports gay marriage, they can just overturn the ban.  It's just going to be a constant back-and-forth.  It's better to let each state decide for themselves.  They're the ones who will have to live with the consequences of their decision.

Okay, so, think about it this way. Myspace is like a public bulletin board, right? Anything you put on there is for everyone to see, not just your friends.  So, if school officials can see it, even if they aren't using the school's name, it's not really a big deal. 

I mean, if they're checking Myspace to make sure students aren't doing anything dangerous, like drinking or smoking, that's different. It's like they're trying to catch kids doing something wrong, which is kind of wrong. But if they're trying to prevent something bad from happening, like a school shooting, then I think it's okay.  

It's all about keeping everyone safe, you know?  Schools have a responsibility to protect their students, and sometimes that means looking into things even if it feels a little bit like an invasion of privacy. 

Plus, think about it, if you post something on the internet, it's out there forever. Even if you delete it, someone could have already seen it.

Okay, so, about this war... at first, I was totally for it. Nine Eleven hit me hard, you know? I was ready to dish out some payback, same as they did here. But looking back, I think our emotions got the best of us. We jumped in without a real plan, kinda unprepared. And it backfired big time. 

Honestly, I'm against it now. I don't think it achieved anything.  Those people over there, they're too busy fighting each other to bother with us.  They can't even get along, so what difference does us being there make?

Nine Eleven changed things for me. I just don't care what happens to them anymore. It's like they're not even human, the way they fight each other. They can't solve their own problems.

We went in there blind, not knowing what we were facing. War for them is different than it is for us. They're savage. They're not trying to build anything, they just want us out.  And honestly, I think we should just leave.

I think we were just hyped up by the whole thing, not thinking straight about the consequences. We were fueled by revenge, and President Bush just went along with it because the people wanted it. 

I get why he declared war on Iraq. We couldn't just let them get away with it. But we should've had a better plan. We were disorganized and unclear about our goals. There was no unity. 

We were driven by anger and emotion, and that's what we created over there. Honestly, I don't think we're capable of changing them. They'll always be like that.

I've said enough. It's been dragging on for too long. We've made some progress, but not enough to justify staying.  They'll just fall apart again once we leave. We can't be there forever.
